Award.AwardTitle: IPY: Collaborative Research: A Prototype Network for Measuring Arctic Winter Precipitation and Snowcover (Snow-Net)
Award.AbstractNarration: A prototype international network is proposed to measure snowfall and ground snow at 5 arctic sites concurrently in an effort to improve the ability to monitor. All of the sites have been identified as key locations in a pan-arctic monitoring network and will augment existing meteorological and snow measuring instrumentation with solid-state snow pillows, heated plate precipitation sensors, snow fences, and eddy correlation towers for computation of sublimation. Ground surveys will also be conducted for snow cover depth, water equivalent, and other properties using tools that allow rapid collection of extensive data. These will be augmented with aerial photography and airborne remote sensing from inexpensive platforms (kites and UAVs) to visualize drift and deposition patterns. The combined suite of instruments and measurements is designed to allow closure of the winter water balance at each site, for the first time balancing the precipitation with measured accumulation. Using a set of modeling tools (e.g., a melt model, and a transport model for blowing snow), the PI's will a) develop methods and algorithms for quality checking both meteorological and snow data by cross-comparison between sensors and instruments, b) close the water balance in a way that produces more accurate values of winter precipitation and snow on the ground than are currently being collected, and c) apply a methodology to historical data from the existing gauge network to produce better estimates of past trends.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Satellite observations and climate models show that Arctic snow is changing. Station snow and precipitation data are recognized to be challenging to interpret, because of the spatially sparse observational network and variations in that network over time. In addition, existing long-term precipitation measurements in the Arctic are unreliable due to wind and frequent blowing snow events. However, the prolonged presence of snow in the Arctic and sub-Arctic (at least six to nine months of the year) makes snow a critical energy, water and ecosystem component. This component needs to be measured in more places, for less money, with higher accuracy.  

We aggregated a number of measurement approaches into several selected Arctic sites to evaluate their performance. We found that gauged-based assessment of precipitation continued to be unreliable. However, our ability to measure snow depths over space and time was outstanding, and we recommend more attention paid to this precipitation metric instead of traditional gauge-catch estimates. The relationship between precipitation and snow on the ground, shown on the accompanying figure, features the snow transport component. We estimated snow movement using snow fences, reporting that relatively few windy storm events move most of the snow. Importantly, we developed automated and more efficient field-based methods to measure snow quickly, safely, and accurately at our sites. SnowNet II is now focusing on making these methods more economical so they become more widespread.
